is a manmade conglomerate of concrete containing 10 parts Portland cement to 1 part fine aggregate. It has been a standard construction material and is more durable than plain reinforced concrete and as strong as ordinary concrete. As such, it is a preferred medium for building structures such as foundations, columns, beams, and slabs. The concrete can range in size from 2 to 5 inches in thickness and generally has a water-cementitious ratio anywhere from 0.4 to 0.7. An excessive water content will cause segregation, while an incorrect ratio may cause failure of the hardened concrete. In order to achieve a good concrete mix that is sufficiently plastic, the water content must be controlled using the so-called concrete-water requirements. Although the actual requirements depend on several factors, in general, the water content must account for 6 to 7% of the aggregate. In this way, when the concrete is mixed with water, a paste with a high hydration rate will be formed. As shown in Figure 1, water hydrates with cement to form calcium silicate hydrate. When water is present, calcium silicate hydrate will be formed. The calcium silicate hydrate, which is known as the hydration reaction, causes the hardening of the concrete. If the water level of the concrete is too high, the concrete will be weak. When concrete is mixed, the water-cementitious ratio can also be controlled. Water is essential because the cement must have enough water in order to activate the calcium limes. Therefore, when the water is excessive, the water-lime reaction produces an excessive amount of calcium hydrate, while in the presence of less water, the calcium hydrate reaction will take place.

instruction: Unemployment is a situation where people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job. There are different types of unemployment, such as frictional, structural, cyclical, and seasonal unemployment. Explain what each type of unemployment means, and how they are measured by official statistics. Give an example of a factor that can cause or reduce each type of unemployment.
combined_input: Unemployment is a situation where people who are willing and able to work cannot find a job. There are different types of unemployment, such as frictional, structural, cyclical, and seasonal unemployment. Explain what each type of unemployment means, and how they are measured by official statistics. Give an example of a factor that can cause or reduce each type of unemployment. StatisticsThis Method PostEqualoe Canada
generated_output:
Answer. A type of unemployment that occurs as a result of an increase in the demand for workers, and a decrease in the supply of workers; cyclical unemployment is caused by general economic conditions. Measured by official statistics using unemployment rate; the employment rate measures how many people are working vs. the total work force. Wage cuts lead to the unemployment rate remaining high. There is less incentive for people to search for jobs or to accept low pay. Statistics: Employer (employee) taxes are included in the price to be paid for goods and services. Taxes increase prices, and reduce buying power. These higher prices (inflation) also discourage buyers from buying more goods and services, resulting in lower sales. Economic Conditions: Increases in the supply of low wage workers increase competitive labour supply and drive down average wages. Employers can then offer less to workers in search of job, and this results in greater unemployment because some people in the labour force are not prepared to accept lower wages.
Explanation:The type of Unemployment is a situation which occurs when a person does not have a job for different reasons. According to the economists, there are four types of unemployment: 1. Friction Unemployment: In the frictional type of unemployment, a person does not have a job due to some friction. It is of two types: 1. Voluntary Unemployment: A person is voluntarily unemployed if he rejects a job due to some personal reasons. 2. Involuntary Unemployment: A person is involuntarily unemployed if he is unemployed because of some physical cause. 2. Seasonal Unemployment: In a particular season a person doesn’t have a job because of the nature of seasonal work. 3. Structural Unemployment: If a person is unemployed because the nature of industries he wants to enter into is shrinking, he is involved in the Structural Unemployment. 4. Cyclical Unemployment:Cy...

What lessons from the past could be applied today?The labor movement in the United States is quite unlike any of our sister countries. This is due to a number of factors; the least important of which is that in our country workers in the first half of the nineteenth century did not have to organize unions. By 1800, all workers were free and land had been subdivided so that no one had a dominant position in society and therefore could not dominate anybody else. This is unlike today when we have an increasingly unlevel playing field: a few individuals like Bill Gates and Warren Buffett have as much money as the lowest wages of 70% of US workers. There were also a few major causes of the labor movement â the growth of capitalism, the Industrial Revolution, and unbridled greed. All of the above have been around ever since man has been around, but only in the latter part of the nineteenth century did capitalism overtake agrarianism. Bank Rate - Inflation
Bank Rate is a rate of interest charged on overnight borrowing for banks by the central bank (the Reserve Bank in the case of Australia). The Reserve Bank of Australia is also responsible for reducing the level of inflation (a target of 2 to 3 percent per year) through its ability to affect the money supply available to the banking system. It does this by increasing the bank reserve requirement or by adjusting the cash rate. For example, if the Reserve Bank raises the bank reserve requirement when interest rates are already high, the effect on bank borrowing will be relatively small. If the Reserve Bank decreases the bank reserve requirement when the cash rate is already low, then the available funds for bank borrowings will substantially increase. This will effectively lower the interest rate set by the market to match a new level of demand for funds. There's more to reading a textbook than just reading word for word. It's about understanding the material. The author also seems to not have any idea about why something is true. It might seem that you know lots of facts already, but do you really know why a fact is true? When you start to really think about something, you can see that there is no other explanation for it being true. When I see an equation like e = mc2, I can see how true it is. If I see an equation with a squared in it, I can see it means something else, but I can't explain it. The way to learn a complex subject like physics is by getting a grasp of the subject, not by memorizing equations. Memorizing equations is a way to know something without actually knowing something. This is more about learning than an equation. It isn't just how you interpret mathematical equations. I could explain this in more detail and go in to how that works. In fact I could write a whole article about the subject. But this article is already too long, so that will have to be one for another time. I'm sure there are better things to do than to get a solid grasp of the fundamentals and then work from that. I'm sure there are many sources that would have told the author that. ### 1004 Theoretical Foundations and Analysis of Explainable Machine Translation
### **This paper proposes a theoretical framework of explainability of automatic machine translation, which provides key concepts for model design and theoretic guidance for interpreting/improving existing MT explanations.**

1. Could the authors provide more in-depth definitions of the terms "dynamical-decision" and "context-sensitive"? And could the author show more empirical studies to support these decisions?
2. Could the authors provide more examples to showcase how the proposed theoretical model guides the design of interpretability techniques?

## 9004 Theoretical Foundations and Analysis of Explainable Machine Translation

\section{A Computational Framework to Model the Human Cognitive System for Machine Readability}
\subsection{Human Cognitive Flexibility and Its Corresponding Computational Metaphor in Computer Vision}
Human cognitive flexibility is a form of general cognitive factor, which refers to ability to adapt to different situations and tasks (Kingstone et al., 2015). Based on existing cognitive theory (Simonton, 1988), computer vision cognitive flexibility (CVCF) is defined in this experiment of CVCF as the ability of computers to adapt to different tasks and models easily. It is measured by how fast and accurate computers can generalize different concepts, such as different classifiers for one data and different datasets for same model. The proposed research has verified that CVCF is positively correlated with the speed of recognition accuracy and negatively correlated with the number of epochs needed to training networks (Rank et al., 2020). To enhance CVCF, the training strategy is used to train model and adapt the model to different datasets or tasks.

\subsection{Machine Readability and its Requirements}
The notion of "machine readability" refers to an indicator that measures how humans can understand the decisions made by the machine. The theory is that if humans understand the machine better, they can make the machine more intelligent (Szegedy et al., 2015; Hohman et al., 2017; Nallapati et al., 2016).

A common criterion for human comprehension of the prediction algorithm is the human judgment criterion (Rusu et al., 2017a) which specifies a measure of human judgment about the model (Rusu et al., 2017b). This can be defined as "the predicted probability of the class $c$ in a single input should be the highest probability of every class of images in human interpretation" (Rusu et al., 2017b). This evaluation criterion is only applicable when the ground-truth images are the same as the predicted images. When the ground-truth images are different from the predicted images, this criterion also requires more interpretation of the model and it may not meet users' needs.

We propose another criteria, namely "the predicted image should follow human interpretation". Human interpretation is a general criterion that can apply to a variety of machine learning tasks. In other words, the human judgment criterion is equivalent to the machine interpretation criterion.

In our experiment, we take machine reading as an example to present the explanation of the machine reading task.

\subsection{The Focus on the Machine Interpretation Criteria}
When we consider the "interpretability" feature of machine learning methods in text and image processing tasks, the basic principle of computer vision is that data in the same class are close to each other, while other data are far from each other. The model must accurately describe this principle in order to extract patterns or rules that can generate correct judgment criteria. Therefore, computer vision methods can only explain part of the classification results. But when we consider the machine interpretation criterion, this is only a part of the classification results, because humans can understand these classification results, and human interpretability criteria are not only the same as machine interpretation, but more accurate than that. Therefore, the generalization theory of human interpretation and understanding is introduced here to demonstrate that machine readability is also a concept that can accurately describe the model's understanding of humans.

#### What Makes Machine Interpretability?

Machine reading is based on the following criteria. \begin{enumerate}
\item For example, in a face recognition system, if an object is recognized as a face, users should know that it is a human face, and if it is not a face, they should not think it is a human face.
\item If the system determines that a specific image is a human face, the model should be accurate.
\item The predicted probability of the model is not always accurate, which makes it impossible for humans to understand what the model is doing incorrectly.
\end{enumerate}

Following this model, the machine interpretation criteria for image classification can be presented as follows

\medskip

\begin{enumerate}
\item \emph{For example:} If the model recognizes a picture, I will identify it as $I$.
\item \emph{If:} Identify $I$ as an image and then predict \begin{equation}
\argmax \Pr(P|X) \not = I
\end{equation}
\end{enumerate}

In general, when the input is identified as an image and the output is not the image predicted by the model, the model cannot correctly interpret humans and has poor explanatory power. The predicted image is not necessarily correct due to a variety of reasons such as data defects and randomness.

If this happens often in the model, human understanding is not good, or if the model always makes mistakes, the quality of model explanations will be very poor.
In short, the machine interpretation criterion of machine reading is to judge the model from human perspective, which is related to the accuracy of the model, and it is not affected by the randomness of data.

\section{Improving Machine Readability Through Cognitive Flexibility}

\paragraph{Cognitive Flexibility of Model}
A commonly used method to enhance the flexibility of models is model aggregation, which can combine different models for the same task to reduce flexibility (Rank et al., 2020). The advantage of model combination is the reduction of the number of hyperparameters that need to be adjusted in the model training process, which can reduce parameter sensitivity and improve the interpretability of model predictions.

\subsection{Improving Human Cognitive Flexibility}
In this experiment, we use the technique of model aggregation to try to enhance machine reading ability through cognitive flexibility.

We first compare the quality of machine readability of different training strategies (Table \ref{Tab:Trainstrategies}).
Table~\ref{Tab:Trainstrategies} and the experimental results show that by combining different models into one network, we can increase the speed of recognition (10.78s to 6.05s) and improve the accuracy of recognition (80.85\% to 81.59\%). It also decreases the convergence time (25 to 5) and improves network training accuracy and speed. We also observed that the accuracy of the training process was improved from 80.85\% to 81.59\%, which is consistent with human cognition, which uses various resources, such as memory and processing speed, to adapt to different tasks (Lavie, 1995; Fell, 2010). This shows that human cognitive flexibility can be achieved through training. This also means that adaptive models can better understand new tasks compared to traditional models.

\paragraph{Improving Human Cognitive Flexibility}

In addition, this experiment shows that model aggregation can help reduce the error of model predictions. It also demonstrates that the performance of cognitive models can be improved through model aggregation. When model aggregation is implemented by different models, it can make full use of the resource advantages of different models, which can further improve the model's inference and reduce the randomness of the prediction (Rank et al., 2020). In other words, the cognitive model with high accuracy can extract more useful and effective features for the prediction task than traditional models, which reduces the amount of randomness and improves the flexibility of cognitive models.

\subsection{Human Judgment Criteria}
In the experiment, the training strategy used the cross entropy calculation function to train the model, which increases the speed of model recognition. The human judgment criterion can help the model to better understand the problem and to achieve good performance (Ly et al., 2009).

\section{Conclusion}

In this paper, we present a theoretical framework for the definition of human flexibility and propose the human judgment criterion, which is based on the notion of human flexibility. The model's interpretation ability can be defined as the model's understanding of human judgment. Machine flexibility can be used to judge the machine's interpretation. In order to explain human interpretation criteria, we propose a training method for adaptive learning machines.

In this paper, we propose a theoretical framework for the definition of human flexibility and propose human judgment criteria as a basis for understanding machine interpretability. Specifically, from the human cognitive point of view and the training strategy, it can be observed that cognitive model methods have a higher quality of machine readability than traditional methods and can be applied to a variety of machine learning tasks.

In this paper, we take image classification as an example to demonstrate the explanation of human interpretation criteria, and propose a training strategy to reduce network inference time. This paper also introduces human cognitive flexibility and its corresponding cognitive model (Human Cognitive Flexibility and Its Corresponding Cognitive Model), and proposes a new training strategy to improve cognitive models. We also demonstrate the effect of cognitive model enhancement on human understanding.

In this paper, we also proposed that a high-quality cognitive model can better understand new tasks compared to traditional models. This shows that, compared to other models, different cognitive models can use different strategies to adapt to different tasks. In these experiments, we proposed that the quality of machine readability and interpretability can be improved through cognitive model enhancement. This paper also presents a new explanation method for models. It can be used by practitioners to explain some features of models to the general public.

\subsection{Future Work}

In the future, we will further explore and improve human cognitive flexibility. Future work will focus on applying advanced cognitive models to interpret traditional models and enhancing explainable machine learning methods (Agarwal and Koczy, 2018).
Future work will also explore how to use these models to improve explainable machine learning and its application value.

This paper explores machine interpretability and how to apply cognitive model strategies to machine interpretation. In future work, we will continue to explore machine reading's application value and explore ways to improve model interpretability.

The proposed cognitive model strategy can be further experimentally verified in other tasks such as face recognition, and the proposed method can also help improve the flexibility of cognitive models.

\section{Explanation Strategies for Explaining Cognitive Modelling}

We present various interpretability and explainability research methods in the field of model interpretation.

## Model Interpretability

Explainable Machine Learning (XML) is a field of research that aims to provide an intuitive explanation of the underlying principles of how a neural network works by presenting examples of its application (Agarwal and Koczy, 2018). Explainable machine learning is used to facilitate better communication and collaboration between scientists, which can help create better explainable methods.
Explainability in machine learning can also serve as an information layer that can be used to explain the model's behavior to the public.

Explainable AI seeks to give people a better understanding of how machine learning makes decisions so that humans don't have to understand the entire ML model in order to make a decision. AI and machine learning (ML) are becoming increasingly important in our world of technology (Ly, 2016; Ly and Gu, 2015). Explainable AI is the process of making machine learning models interpretable to users, so they can understand how the models work and make informed decisions.

\subsection{Explanation Techniques for ML Models}
In model interpretation, explanations are often considered the process of interpreting how a machine learning model produces predictions and interpretations on data.
In fact, ML is an iterative process that relies on the human understanding of ML to make correct decisions based on the data.
Explainability in ML can refer to the interpretation and explanation of the model as well as the underlying principles which may be different but in some cases, the same as the explanation of the model.
Explainability refers to how the underlying principles are interpreted from machine learning models, and these principles describe how ML works.

In this paper, we propose theoretical model understanding and a training strategy to understand machine learning.

Explainability and interpretation are used interchangeably to express the degree to which models are able to explain themselves to users, and the degree to which they can explain to humans how they make predictions in order to make decisions (Chamberlain and Lerchs, 2020a). We present and analyze the explanatioin approach in this paper (Table \ref{Table:Exaplanation}).

\begin{table} [h]
\tabcaption{\protect\caption{Techniques for Explainable Machine Learning.}\label{Table:Exaplanation}\tabcolsep1.5pt\centerline{\begin{tabu}{lcc}
\hline
\textbf{Technique} & \textbf{Description} \\\hline\hline
\textbf{Abstraction} & \textbf{Abstraction is used to create abstractions and refinements of abstractions.} \\
\textbf{Attribute Interpretation} & \textbf{Attribute Interpretation is a technique that uses a classifier to predict a class and an attribute.} \\
\textbf{Attribute Localization} & \textbf{Class Attribute Localization is a process that classifies an image from the features in it.}
\\
\textbf{Behavior Pattern} & \textbf{A behavior pattern can be seen as more than just a property or as a system in which a system's internal states can be derived from its external behaviour.} \\
\textbf{Causal Tree} & \textbf{Causal tree is a tree-type structure in which causality is represented by path-based dependencies.} \\
\textbf{Centrolity Diagram} & \textbf{The technique uses a centroid to represent an image.} \\
\textbf{Decision Trees} & \textbf{The method works by applying decision tree to an image.} \\

How can you improve your paper writing in academic style by using effective transitions and signposts? What are the functions and types of transitions and signposts in academic writing? How can you use them to connect your ideas and guide your reader? An example of a paragraph that lacks transitions and signposts is:

The main cause of global warming is the greenhouse effect. Greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere and warm up the Earth’s surface. Carbon dioxide is the most important greenhouse gas. It is produced by burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas. The more fossil fuels we burn, the more carbon dioxide we emit.
You need to polish the paragraph.

Bibliography pages need to be double-spaced, and they may not have a title. References or Bibliography is the last pages of written work where the readers can find sources of information to support your ideas and statements. There are two primary purposes for using a works cited page:.
It is important to understand the basic parts of a bibliography so that your paper contains the right elements and is easy to read and use. The author will have a different name depending on the style they used.

How To Create A Works Cited Page For A Research Paper
But a Works Cited page is different. You should not include it in the first draft of your paper or in any revisions of your paper, but you should do it if your instructor asks you to create one. You should ask your instructor if you have to create a Works Cited page to cite your sources.
You can see that not all bibliographies are the same. In this example, the authors' name is omitted because it is already included in parentheses.
There are certain differences in MLA and APA formatebibliography formatting. Below is the format for your bibliography page: An annotated bibliography does not have to provide an APA format bibliography page.
In addition, you will need to number each entry, in order. The first entry is 1. For more information, please visit our Citing Sources guide.
You can get more help about how to write and format bibliographies by clicking here.
There is no need to list them in alphabetical order. If you are citing multiple sources from the same author, list them alphabetically by the titles of their works.
Use quotation marks if it is a short phrase. Use italics for longer passages. If you are including more than one book, list them on one line per book with a space in between.
Include the full title of the book. If it is a chapter in an anthology, list the editor surname here first, the chapter title and chapter number. Here are some annotated bibliography examples: You can find the example of MLA citation style with annotations at the following page.
MLA Citation Guide (8th Edition): Annotated Bibliography
You may need to revise it later. It is important to note that you are working on it even if you do not have a final version. If your professor has requested an annotated bibliography, he or she will tell you what type you need to submit. There are two main types of annotated bibliographies, those that have an annotation for every source you are summarizing and those that have an annotation for the entire project.
The first will allow you more space to explain why that source was significant, while the second will allow you to write a short reflection about what you have learned through your research. You will only need to summarize each source at first.
But for the project, write a paragraph that will include a sentence about each of your sources. Here is an example of how this would look when it was written on a separate document.
While these citations can be used on a works cited page, they can also be used on a bibliography page so it does not matter which specific page you are working on at the moment. This will ensure your teacher will be able to find it quickly. Your bibliography should include the name of the author, publication date, medium or publication description and the publisher.
For example, a book will follow this specific example: There is even more you can include if you are citing online resources or other materials that are not a print publication. An annotated bibliography for research paper mla example. If the website name is not readily available, you should include this in your citation as well.
For help with formatting an MLA annotated bibliography, check out our MLA formatting guide. Some things to note about a bibliography page: The bibliography page will also follow the correct MLA heading and format. Make sure your bibliography page aligns on the page and that the page number is correct. Write your references the same as you wrote your works cited page. Use the same order that you used to list your sources in your research paper.
Include a full title as well as a title for your bibliography page. As you have probably come to realize, all formats and styles of writing have guidelines, rules and instructions on how to format and write your research paper and annotated bibliography. These styles include APA, MLA and Chicago just to name a few.
When you are creating an annotated bibliography, you need to do it with a specific format in order for it to be viewed as a completed and correct research paper. A bibliography page is a page where you list all your sources used during your research process. An annotated bibliography is a bibliography that is more in-depth than your typical bibliography.
What is a bibliography for a research paper? Your bibliography is a page where you list all the sources you used for your research paper. While creating your document it is important to make sure that you have included in your paper a bibliography page and a works cited or references page. Your bibliography will include the name of the author, the name of the publication, medium and the complete name of the publisher.

Which of the following substances is the most toxic to humans based on its median lethal dose (LD50)?

A) Arsenic B) Cyanide C) Mercury D) Botulinum toxin
combined_input:
Which of the following substances is the most toxic to humans based on its median lethal dose (LD50)?

A) Arsenic B) Cyanide C) Mercury D) Botulinum toxin StatisticsThis Method PalEqual margin Canada
generated_output:
.
It is a normal part of biology for cells to undergo programmed cell death, the process of which is collectively called apoptosis. It's a highly regulated process that occurs in many places during life. To survive an attack by disease or injury, or during development, many cells die through programmed cell death. This process is called apoptosis and it can cause cell death either by direct mechanical damage to cell membranes, or by activation of intracellular mechanisms, such as cleavage of proteins by caspase enzymes.

An example of apoptotic cell death is the removal of damaged cells. The immune system can produce the apoptotic cell death of cancer cells in a process called antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC). Such cells are marked for destruction through a complex and long process involving many cell types, molecules, and mechanisms with specificity and sensitivity to the stage of cancer and how late it progressed within the specific organ or tissue in which the cancer was.

This leads to activation of caspase enzymes and apoptosis. Apoptosis is the process by which a cell's DNA is broken down into its component parts.

This leads to activation of caspase enzymes and apoptosis. Apoptosis is the process by which a cell's DNA is broken down into its component parts. It is not programmed cell death; it is triggered by something like an injury or infection that kills the cell.

1. Neutralization of cancer cells from the immune system by antibodies
2. Identification of cancer cells by the immune system
3. Attraction to and removal of the cancer cells by macrophages and related white blood cells that are part of the immune system
4. Killing of the cancer cells by cells of the immune system

These cells become more effective when they have receptors on their surface that bind to antibodies, allowing the immune system to know the identity of a given virus or bacterium, and to react accordingly to kill them. The cells themselves, therefore, are a target, an intermediate target, or a bystander. Cells that are killed by ADCC are called effector cells.

The target cells are killed when the effector cells activate or kill them. Cell debris and cellular fragments that remain are called cell residues. The cell residues are detected and identified by the immune system and can then trigger other steps or further activation. In general, cells can be destroyed when the target cells are killed.

The immune system can kill cells that are not targets. These are called bystander cells. They are destroyed when the same cell death mechanisms are used. Cells in the body that are damaged by radiation can activate the apoptotic process to remove themselves from the body. These are called inducers of apoptosis. Apoptosis is a very precise process that must be balanced so that it is efficient and effective.

Cells use a complex and elaborate set of mechanisms to destroy the DNA in their nuclei and thus kill themselves.

An alternative approach to using historical data to forecast the level of employment is to use a time series model to forecast. A time series is a sequence of data points indexed by time. The series can also be thought of as a collection of observations on a variable. For example, we can model the weekly number of shoppers at a supermarket with a time series model for shopper sales. If our independent variable x is the week and our dependent variable y is
shopper sales, the time series would resemble the following:
This table does not show the actual values of observations on the
variable x, but they all have a value of 1 which is the period

Time series models allow us to model the evolution of variables such as unemployment or inflation so we are interested in their predictions rather than their absolute levels (which change over time).
The general form of a time series model is
y = a + bx where: a: an intercept c: constant or level to which the variable y would ideally be if there were no influence from x b: an influence from x It is important to be note that the y variable in our equation must have the same units as those of the underlying variable of interest, so if the level of the variable is 12 in the x variable, then the level of the variable y is also 12.
4.1 Simple Forecasts
A simple prediction of a time series is: the forecast of the variable y n is y n = y n 1 + (b*x n1), where: y n : predicted value of y n b : coefficient of b term in time series c : level of b term in time series x n 1 : values of the independent variable x n
Figure 5: Predicting the US Unemployment Rate (1) Source: FactSet, BLS
The forecasts generated by the simple forecast model have no smoothing. Unlike the simple forecasts, exponential smoothing is a
forecasting method that incorporates trend and seasonal smoothing.
4.2 Exponential Smoothing
Exponential Smoothing is a method to estimate the future values of variables that take values over time. In financial markets, such variables would typically be stock prices. The exponential smoothing method is applied to the raw observation of the value (y
t), and then a smoothed version of the data is formed. This is done to show an overall increasing or decreasing trend within the data, with corrections made based on the most recent data. To calculate the smoothed value (y
t+m), the exponential smoothing method uses the previous value of y
t,y
t-1to be the forecast. This is done in the form
yt+m
yt-1 = r+b where: r = trend factor =
b = level factor When r = 1, then the forecast is linear. When r > 1 (negative values are also possible), then the forecast tends to increase more quickly than the underlying time series. When r < 1, then the forecast tends to decrease. A high value of r
(close to 1) would indicate that the forecast is made using the trend information to a high extent; a low value would indicate that the trend and seasonal information is not considered in the forecast. As with a simple forecast, the constant b is the level of the time series. In general, b is set to the median of the values. Exponential Smoothing is also used to forecast stock prices or other variables that take an arbitrary number of values (such as steps or counts); however, the most common type of smoothing applied to stock prices, which we focus on, is linear smooth (usually, linear regression).
4.3 Linear Smooth
Linear Smooth makes an attempt to estimate the future values of an
indicator as a straight line that approximates the series as closely as possible. In this case, it is assumed that when the indicator reaches a new value, it does so in a linear fashion (i.e., that there is no inflection point).
The forecast for the t+1 period is given as the weighted average of y
t and the predicted values of y
t. Except for small initial errors, this makes our initial forecast approximately linear; that is, y-hat t+1 = b. t y
Figure 6: Linear Smooth Example Source: FactSet, BLS
The weighting or smoothing factor ( ) = (1) (w
+w b
w +w
) is usually set at 50%. That is, the initial forecast (y-hat t-1) gets twice the weight of the past observations.
4.4 Error Measurement
Many statistical studies involve the use of forecasting error. These errors are generally reported for the next three to five months after each set of forecasts is released.
The forecasting error is the forecast for a time period less that an actual value for that time period. Thus a forecast of GDP for the fourth quarter for the full year is compared with the actual GDP for the fourth quarter.
In most forecasting systems, the forecasting error is measured by taking the difference between the forecast and the actual, and then adding this difference to the sum of the errors from prior intervals as follows
= E1 + E2 + E3 + E4 +
This equation assumes a random walk process. Thus, each error (Eij) is assumed to have
no relation or bias to prior errors. This is obviously a simplification of the forecasting process, which involves adjustments that are based at least in part on the information. However, our goal will be to demonstrate the use of these error
measures, and to show how we can use them to judge the quality of our forecasts.
There are many methods of measuring the error. Below are a few of the most common methods.
4.4.1 Mean Absolute Error
The mean absolute error (MAE) for an i-th observation is E
i = |yi t
yi t+1|.
In MAE, the forecast and the observation values are assumed to be the same at any time, and there is no time trend. Thus, no attempt is made to correct for the forecast of one month to the forecast of the next month. MAE is computed for each month and the MAE for the year is the sum of the monthly MAE values for each month.
4.4.2 Root-Mean Squared Error
The root of the mean square error (RMSE) is given by
= i=1
Ei = i i=1
Ei = 1
The RMSE is the square root of the sum of the squared forecasting errors. Thus the RMSE will be larger than the mean absolute error when the forecasting error is large or varies greatly.
4.4.3 Mean Absolute Scaled Error
The mean absolute scaled error (MASE) is like the root mean square error (RMSE), but takes into account the
differences in the magnitude of Y1 and the Y2 values as follows
Ei = Ei yi t/yi t+1
where: yi t is the forecast, yi t+1 is the actual value, and yi t/yi t+1 is the scaled error.
4.4.4 Mean Absolute Revised Error
The mean absolute revised error (MARE) has a similar computation to MASE. It is computed as follows:
Ei = Ei (yi t/yi t+1).
MARE is a measure that adjusts the magnitude of an error by the ratio of the forecast
and the actual observation.
5.0 Forecasting the Employment Situation
Forecasting the monthly number of new jobs created in the US is a
complex task involving the use of multiple models by economists. There are a large number of models, including the following:
5.1 Leading Economic Indicators Index: a group of ten indicators of economic activity from a wide range of sources, derived from the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER).
5.2 Consumer Expectations Survey: one of the monthly surveys conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank, to
measure the level of consumer expectations with respect to such issues as employment, spending and inflation.
5.3 ADP National Employment Report: this is an independently calculated estimate made by ADP (automatic data processing) of the monthly employment change in the non-farm private sector (that is, excluding government).
5.4 Labor Force Participation Rate: when unemployment rises, the labor force participation rate also increases. Therefore a low labor force participation rate may indicate that unemployment has stopped rising because those looking for work have given up.
5.5 Personal Consumer Expenditures: the monthly percentage change in the value of goods and services purchased by households.
These and other economic indicators provide a useful guide for forecasters. However, the unemployment level is highly influenced by the business cycle and cannot be forecasted easily by economic indicators such as interest rates, GDP growth and the like. If the state of consumer health and confidence is low, then consumers will not go out shopping, causing businesses to downsize. It is a catch-22 situation where consumers will not spend money so businesses can not employ people (for which they provide the primary source of income). The government uses statistical techniques to model the number of unemployed people. The US Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) collect data every month from more than 100 different household surveys. This data is used by the government to calculate various economic indicators, including unemployment rates. The data gathering includes two key surveys of unemployment: a household survey and an establishment survey. For the purpose of the unemployment rate calculations, the household survey asks three key questions: how many people are actively looking for a job, how people are searching for a job and what is the average hours worked over a two-week period. The questions from the establishment survey are: how many jobs are filled and how many workers are on short-time hours (i.e. working less than 35 hours
a week). Forecasts are made by the BLS based on a time series model that adjusts for the business cycle. The government takes into account how
consumer confidence levels, payroll growth and unemployment data are performing.
Figure 7: US Unemployment Source: FactSet, BLS
The best models for employment and inflation in the United States have been created by the Federal Reserve Bank. It has become more important in recent years for the bank to be able to predict how the economy will perform in the future. This has led to increasingly sophisticated methods.
The Federal Reserve Model (FRBmodel) employs a vector autoregressive (VAR) approach. Here we only examine the VAR approach and leave out other models (such as Phillips Curve or a Kalman Filter method) for the purposes of simplicity and brevity. The FRB model does not explain the level of the dependent variables it
forecasts, instead it focuses on forecasting changes in the level. The FRB model assumes that all data in the VAR depend simultaneously on previous values of all other data. In the FRB model, forecasts are done on a monthly basis (instead of daily as the models of the individual markets); however, data on previous months is included in these forecasts to provide a longer term view of the economy. To do this, the Federal Reserve (FR) uses a VAR that consists of one equation to forecast and one equation to project. The forecast equation has only four terms that forecast the future level of the variable of interest without considering the levels of other variables. The projection equation is just a modified version of the forecast equation and includes the changes in the dependent variable in this equation. Using these equations, the FRB can forecast short term changes in the level of unemployment. The main focus of the present analysis is on two forecasts: 1. Unemployment rate: the percentage of the entire civilian labor force that are unemployed (defined as actively looking for employment but unable to find work). 2. Total Non-Farm Payrolls: jobs
(unadjusted, seasonal, and total) from across many industries within the United States. There are a number of other forecasts used by the FRB that we are not focusing on here; however, those other forecasts are used to calibrate the forecasts by the method described below. Before these forecasts are used, they are revised to be consistent with each other. While this is not the subject of this note, it is important to state that the Federal Reserve is trying to find an objective method of doing this (i.e., what is the right way to incorporate past forecast data in such a way that makes the best consistent forecasts without overdoing it). There is a great variety in forecasts for inflation produced by banks, economists, and the government. The focus of this analysis is on forecasts of inflation and short-term changes in employment.
6.1 Forecasting Unemployment
This is the percentage change in the number of jobs in a month.
6.2 Forecasting Inflation
Inflation involves forecasting the changes to price levels that occur due to business cycles with the help of economic indicators. The BLS calculates consumer prices by sampling households and businesses throughout the nation. They measure the average change in the cost of products over a twelve-month period which is compared to changes from the previous year. The BLS also takes into account forecasted price changes for certain products used by the government and private industry. For example, they measure the cost of fuel and electricity to determine how much more it will cost to keep heating their houses than it did the previous year. Using these costs combined with various economic indicators (such as payroll numbers, employment numbers, interest rates, and economic forecasts provided from banks and other institutions), the BLS calculates an estimated monthly inflation for the year. In order to do this, they use two monthly numbers from the Consumer Price Index (CPI): the month to month change in the CPI and the percentage change in the CPI.
6.3 Benchmarks
For the two equations to model the forecasting of unemployment and inflation, we
use several data sets as benchmarks:
6.3.1 BLS forecasts (as given by the Federal Reserve Bank) The Federal Reserve Bank (FRB) uses two equations to forecast the future course of employment-the so-called forecasts. The first equation only forecasts the future level of the unemployment rate; the second equation forecasts job growth. We compare the results of the two equations with the data obtained through sampling households for BLS.
6.3.2 Employment Data from ADP The Automatic Data Processing (ADP) survey gathers monthly data on total non-farm
payroll. It uses the same survey as the BLS, but the results are not published until after they are released by the BLS. Therefore, both ADP and BLS provide a better estimate of the job growth numbers reported by the government.
6.3.3 FOMC meeting dates and Federal Funds rate Since changes in Federal Funds rate affect consumer spending, they also affect inflation; therefore it is important that we take the
changes in interest rates into account. Therefore the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meetings and the data obtained from Federal Reserve officials will be used as benchmarks. We will be comparing the values provided by the government/BLS, ADP and FRB with those available from the FOMC meetings. The FOMC monitors the current and future economic conditions to make its interest rate decisions. The Federal Reserve Bank will also use the meetings and their
statements/opinions to forecast inflation.
6.4 Method For Calculating Change in Employment
To calculate the change in employment (as measured by the payroll numbers) we only take into account the non-farm payroll numbers. This is a simplification of the data.

Post by RiverstiX » Tue Jul 23, 2013 5:51 pm
Jake Rivers wrote: How would you solve this using differential equations? I'm not sure how to solve this.
(1) For differential equations, the general way to solve is the variable separation method, aka method of undetermined coefficients.
(2) A linear equation with two variables is
y' = A(y-By^(1/2))
If you let,
y = By^(1/2)
and solve (1/2)y' = A(y-By^(1/2))
you'll get the variable Separation Method.
But that won't help this particular equation.

instruction: Evaluate the integral of (x + 2)/(x^2 + 9) dx from x = 0 to x = 2
combined_input: Evaluate the integral of (x + 2)/(x^2 + 9) dx from x = 0 to x = 2 r Award Method PostEqual marginSpecial
generated_output:
marginTotal
The given integral is
∫ ( x + 2 ) d x = ∫ x d x + ∫ 2 d x
= x ⋅ 4 + 4 + 2 ⋅ 2
= 4 ⋅ 3 + 4
In this case, the above integral can be easily evaluated using the standard technique of substitution and integration by parts. The substitution of u = x and du = dx, the final integral formula turns out
x d x + 1 d x | − dx
= x2 + 9
Note that the original integral is equal to zero because of the identity
∫ a b dx = b a
If you are looking for the total margin, then it will be
Total margin
